XIX. 67. Now there arises in this place a certain rather difficult question, whether at any time new friends, worthy of our friendship, are to be preferred to old, as we usually prefer young and tender horses to old hackS. The doubt is unworthy of a human being3 for there ought not to be any surfeit os friendships as there is of other things. The older ’ friendship ought to be the more pleasant, just as those wines which bear old age well. And the following saying is true, that many bushels of salt must be eaten together that the office of friendship may be fully carried out.
